title: PALEOECOLOGY OF THE GADDIS SITE IN THE UPPER CRETACEOUS AGUJA FORMATION, TERLINGUA, TEXAS
abstract: Diverse faunas at the Gaddis site near Terlingua, Texas are present at four stratigraphic levels along a hill in the Upper Cretaceous Aguja Formation providing a rich fossil record of the transition from an aquatic environment to dry land while recording exceptional events such as predation and wildfires. Given evidence for minimal transport the microvertebrates, macrovertebrates, coprolites, and plants may be reliably utilized for paleoecological analysis. Paleoenvironments shift upsection from nearshore marine, through tidal channel, to swamp, and, finally, to well-vegetated dry land. The faunas change from a basal layer of oysters with shark teeth to a microvertebrate assemblage just above logs with Teredolites borings and pristine leaves. Above the microvertebrates are diverse macrovertebrates including numerous dinosaurs associated with leaves, logs, and scrambling vines. The macrovertebrate layer is a rich assemblage of herbivorous and carnivorous dinosaurs, crocodiles, turtles, and rare pterosaurs. Several skeletal elements exhibit signs of predation that include punctures and gouges that precisely match crocodile and theropod teeth also recovered at the site. Abundant plant material that includes charred vines and logs is likely evidence of wildfires having ranged across the area. The preponderance of young dinosaur remains may support a wildfire scenario. An exposed surface with 24 coprolites, two hadrosaur vertebrae, logs, and in situ stumps caps the section. The larger coprolites are likely dinosaurian. Most contain plant materials while one contains a bone fragments suggesting the presence of herbivorous and carnivorous dinosaurs on the same surface, an occurrence that echoes herbivore/carnivore interactions in the underlying bonebed.

body_text.text: The discovery and description of micro-and macrovertebrate fossils in the Aguja Formation of west Texas have dramatically broadened the understanding of Campanian geology, paleoclimate, and paleoecology of vertebrate communities on Laramidia (Davies 1983; Lehman 1985 Lehman , 1989 Standhardt 1986 Standhardt , 1989 Schiebout et al. 1987; Sankey 1998 Sankey , 2008 Lehman 2001, 2009; Nordt et al. 2003; Sankey et al. 2007; Sankey 2010) . The purpose of this investigation was to identify and describe the fossil communities as they changed through time in the lower part of the upper Aguja Formation at a previously unreported site. Special emphasis was placed on the diverse and occasionally exceptional fossil assemblages at the Gaddis site that differ from those at other Aguja Formation exposures. This study extends the paleoecological analysis of Montgomery and Barnes (2012) in the Javelina Formation into the underlying Aguja Formation as components of a project to analyze paleontologically diverse and data-rich Upper Cretaceous localities in west Texas.

The Aguja Formation is an Upper Cretaceous (Campanian) accumulation of mostly progradational deltaic deposits in the Big Bend of Texas that thicken to the west (Macon 1994; Lehman and Busbey 2007) . The upper shale member of the Aguja records deposition along an advancing shoreline in fluvial floodplain, channel, and swamp paleoenvironments (Lehman 1985) . During the late Campanian the Aguja bonebed at the Gaddis site was probably located approximately 100 km from the shoreline (Atchley et al. 2004) . Depositional models for this lower part of the upper shale member of the Aguja depict a drying marsh-bay facies changing to a more terrestrial, swampy, inland floodplain (Lehman 1982 (Lehman , 1985 (Lehman , 1991 . Arid climatic conditions dried up standing water, and dinosaur remains near watering holes were exposed, trampled, and redeposited by periodic floods (Lehman 1982 (Lehman , 1989 Davies and Lehman 1989) . Slow rates of sedimentation yielded a generally condensed faunal history (Lehman 1985 (Lehman , 1991 . When compared to other Aguja Formation sites the Gaddis site contains a record of this drying transition that is both more complete and is richer in paleoecological details.

The Gaddis site is an isolated, elongated ridge trending east-southeast, west-northwest located approximately 3.5 km south and west of Study Butte, Texas ( Fig. 1) . At the base of the outcrop, a bed of dark red sandstone and unconsolidated silty sand is present on the south side of a covered interval approximately 300 m south of a Terlingua Creek Sandstone outcrop. Above the basal sandstone/sand layer the Gaddis site is similar in lithology to a site described by Sankey (2010) at Rattlesnake Mountain in Big Bend National Park (Fig. 1) The Gaddis site is generally unfossiliferous aside from four horizons that from oldest to youngest contain oysters and shark teeth; microvertebrates above logs with Teredolites borings and well-preserved dicotyledonous leaves; a bonebed that includes numerous mostly disarticulated ornithischian and theropod dinosaurs, crocodiles, turtles, fragments of unidentified vertebrates, coniferous logs, dicotyledonous vines, and thick mats of comminuted plant material; and a surface of small to large coprolites and hadrosaur vertebrae at the top of the exposure. This diverse collection of fossils provided evidence that was utilized in a paleoecological reconstruction documenting the change in faunas produced by an environmental shift from nearshore, shallow marine through floodplain swamp to dry land. The term ''dry land'' is used to refer to a surface that was also clearly covered with terrestrial plants as judged from the inclusions in coprolite surfaces. It remains unknown if this was a welldrained floodplain surface. The surface certainly does not meet the criteria for Sankey's (2001) description of an arid, well-drained floodplain in the Aguja Formation.

Three horizons of fossils play major roles in this reconstruction especially because there is evidence for minimal transport and therefore they all qualify as local. The microvertebrates are an especially rich source of local information about the composition and ecology of the fauna below the dinosaur bonebed. While dinosaur remains are known from numerous areas in the Aguja Formation (Standhart 1986; Rowe et al. 1992; Weil 1992; Cifelli 1994; Sankey 1998 Sankey , 2001 Sankey and Gose 2001; Sankey et al. 2005; Nydam et al. 2014) , microsites are less common. The assemblage at the Gaddis microsite is somewhat dissimilar to those of other Aguja sites. The macrovertebrate assemblage is comprised of numerous taxa that also represent a relatively local fauna given evidence of minimal transport. The usual death, exposure, trampling, and redeposition model described from other Aguja sites (Lehman 1982 (Lehman , 1989 Davies and Lehman 1989) does not apply at the Gaddis site. The 24 coprolites at the Gaddis site are a highly unusual discovery as there is only one published description of a single dinosaur coprolite specimen from the Aguja Formation (Baghai 1996) . The coprolites at the Gaddis site provide evidence, with a modest degree of certainty, that most are probably of herbivorous dinosaur origin based on plant contents, and associated hadrosaur skeletal elements on the same surface. A theropod probably excreted one coprolite that contains a prominent bone fragment. The coprolites perhaps place herbivorous and carnivorous dinosaurs on a contemporaneous surface.

While presenting descriptions and interpretations of the above noted intervals, no detailed analysis of the macrovertebrate remains was undertaken as that research is the purview of other current workers at the Gaddis site who have significant experience and expertise with these particular specimens. Previous research of vertebrate on vertebrate attacks at the Gaddis site (Schwimmer 2002) will be utilized as background for our observations of newly discovered fossils.

The collections recovered from four fossiliferous intervals described herein are the products of excavations dating from the late 1980s to the present. All fossils were collected in place aside from rare oviraptor material that was float. The macrovertebrate bonebed is under careful development as the skeletal elements are frequently discovered broken or even shattered. Bones commonly must be stabilized in the field with butvar and extracted in plaster jackets. In the laboratory, the various components of each bone are disassembled, cleaned and reassembled. It is common for a single skeletal element to be composed of numerous pieces. This process is tedious and ongoing.

The microvertebrate lens was excavated both to collect the entire fossilrich lens, and to maintain context by not including matrix from the underlying leaves and bored logs. Approximately 44 liters of fresh silty mudstone were quarried, soaked, and screenwashed. After drying the mudstone readily went into suspension in hot water containing surfactant. The first run of nine liters of sample was washed on a 63-micron sieve. Because microscopic examination revealed no fossils in the finest fraction of these samples the subsequent 35 liters of material were washed on a 180micron sieve. In addition to bones, teeth, scales, shell, and coprolites, the sieved material contained abundant carbonized wood fragments, shredded leaf litter, amber globules, and gypsum. A Nikon SMZ 1500 binocular microscope was used to pick samples and to photograph specimens. Samples were picked from one-specimen-thick layers sprinkled on 70 3 100 mm picking trays. All microvertebrate elements were picked. No invertebrates were present. No search was conducted for protists in this investigations. Approximately 2,500 elements were recovered as determined by redundant counts using a dry microfossil splitter. Characteristics such as abrasion and fracturing were noted for each tray of specimens. Representative specimens were selected for future isotopic analysis.

The coprolites were subjected to thin sectioning. This process proved more complicated than expected because prolonged contact with water while sawing caused significant sloughing of the exterior surface and crumbling of the interior. Epoxy impregnation of further samples somewhat reduced degradation. Numerous thin sections were made as most contained no obvious evidence of plant or animal remains. Additional samples were preserved for future chemical analysis.

In addition to numerous samples of matrix in each fossiliferous horizon, the entire Gaddis site stratigraphic section was sampled at 1.0 m intervals and processed on a 63-micron sieve for microfossils. None were discovered aside from those described from the microvertebrate layer.

Fossils are reported beginning with the lowest stratigraphic exposure in the ridge, a basal oyster and shark tooth sandstone and progressing upsection through a microvertebrate lens, the macrovertebrate bonebed, and ending with the exposed coprolite surface at the top of the ridge (Fig.  2) . The ridge is isolated, and has no nearby correlative outcrops.

The lowest exposed bed at the Gaddis site is marked by coarse, silty sandstone to unlithified silty sand with abundant broken to pulverized Crassostrea shells. Rare Scapanorhynchus texanus shark teeth were found. Unlike the oyster/shark teeth interval at an approximately equivalent stratigraphic level in the Aguja Formation described by Lewis (2011) , this lowest bed at the Gaddis site has no known Deinosuchus or turtle components.

A 50 cm-long segment of the proximal end of an adult hadrosaur tibia and one fragment of ossified tendon adjacent the tibia were recovered from the silty sand. These identifications were made following comparisons with well-preserved hadrosaur elements from the macrofossil bonebed higher in this section. Patches of small oysters encrust the bone.

Overlying the oyster bed is dark brown sandstone containing horizontal burrows approximately 9 cm in diameter and up to approximately 50 cm in length. This sandstone bed is interrupted by a prominent package of buffcolored unfossiliferous, cross-bedded sandstone.

Stratigraphically above the oyster/shark tooth, sand/sandstone bed and at the northwestern end of the ridge is an approximately 50 cm-thick lens of bored logs, leaf-bearing mudstone, and highly fossiliferous silty mudstone that is markedly unlike the unfossiliferous rock enclosing this lens. Of particular interest is a thin layer of microvertebrates (Montgomery 2012) . Microsites in the Big Bend area provide a rich source of in situ taphonomic and paleoecological data not obtainable from macrofossils. Other advantages of microvertebrate analysis include the resolution of biogeographic differences (such as diversity) between sites (Sankey 200l) . For example, previous work (such as Brinkman 1990; Sankey et al. 2005) illuminated the changes in paleocommunities and paleoenvironments upon a transgressive event at the Campanian/Maastrichtian boundary.

At the base of the microvertebrate lens, five bored gymnosperm logs are oriented roughly NE-SW in layers of silty mudstone punctuated by discontinuous lenses of fine-grained, small-scale, cross-bedded sandstone that grades laterally into enclosing silty mudstone on both sides and into the ridge. The logs are a maximum of 20 cm in diameter, and each contains thousands of clavate-shaped, infilled borings in wood substrate (Fig. 3 ). Logs were bored by different sized organisms. Borings, ranging from 2.0 mm to 3.5 cm in maximum diameter, occur along entire surfaces of the logs, and all are perpendicular to sub-perpendicular to what was originally the outer surface of the log. One hollow log is penetrated with borings all the way around. The base of each boring is rounded-oval in cross section, and borings range from millimeters to several centimeters in length. The borings contain silty mudstone that is identical in both color and texture to the immediately enclosing rock.

Two small, highly abraded hadrosaur caudal centra, one small ankylosaur dermal bone, and a juvenile crocodilian centrum were recovered randomly associated with the logs. Rare but well-preserved broken elements (including beak and claw) of the oviraptor Chirostenotes (Longrich et al. 2013) were discovered in float adjacent and below the microvertebrate lens. Another fragment that further completes this oviraptor claw was recently discovered in float approximately a meter above the microvertebrate layer indicating that this dinosaur was apparently younger than the microvertebrates, and is perhaps coeval with the overlying macrofossil bonebed.

Above the logs is a layer of randomly oriented small twigs overlain by siltstone that is covered by mudstone with a thin and discontinuous layer of well-preserved dicotyledonous leaves upon which the microvertebrate lens rested (Fig. 4) . Rare ferns are also present. Microvertebrate elements are within 1-to 3-cm-thick by approximately 1 m 2 siltstone lens ( Fig. 5 ) that also contained microscopic wood fragments with intergrown gypsum, sharp-edged charcoal fragments, rounded charcoal lumps, coarse sandstone lumps, somewhat larger (up to 1.5 cm long) abraded and rounded bone fragments, clay balls, rare pebbles, and elongated coprolites a few mm in diameter. Most of the microvertebrate elements are 1-5 mm in maximum dimension. No articulated microvertebrates were detected in a stereomicroscopic examination of samples performed before dissolution of the matrix.

The microvertebrate fauna is different from that described by Sankey (2010) as the Gaddis lens contains a preponderance of aquatic, even estuarine elements compared to the terrestrial nature of the microvertebrates in Big Bend National Park. Although the Gaddis site also contains dinosaur eggshell fragments, they are much less common than in other sections (Welch and Sankey 2008) . Dinosaur teeth are absent. Amber globules are common, and range up to approximately 5 mm in maximum dimension. The lens also includes abundant comminuted leaf material.

The Rattlesnake Mountain collection consists of microvertebrates and macrovertebrates in a mixed assemblage (Sankey 2010) . Other upper Aguja Formation microvertebrate localities noted previously include faunal census information at sites located to the north and to the southeast of the Gaddis site. Sankey (2010) reported isolated teeth representing nine genera of ornithischian and saurischian dinosaurs, one of which is a tyrannosaurid. An additional 29 taxa of crocodylians, squamates, turtles, fish, amphibians, and mammals were reported (Sankey 2010) . The relative abundance of sharks and rays in the microfaunas is distinctly greater at the Gaddis site.

The Gaddis microfauna utilized for paleoecological analysis exhibits similarities in diversity to some of those described by other workers in the Aguja (Rowe et al. 1992; Sankey 2008) . Aside from the mammals, no attempt was made to undertake systematic paleontology of the recovered specimens as the purpose of this investigation was simply to evaluate paleoecology within shifting paleoenvironments. Thus, taxa that convey ecological information were most important for our purpose. The identifiable microvertebrate assemblage (including all other elements present) is composed of the following elements in estimated percentages: gar (23.0%), other teleosts (15.0%), sawfish (10.0%), hybodont sharks (8.0%), bonefish (7.0%), other sharks (2.0%), pterosaurs (2.0%), crocodylians (1.0%), turtles (0.5%), amphibians (0.25%), mammals (0.25%), snakes (one tooth), bone fragments (7.0%), amber (5.0%), palm seeds (three), unknown (18.0%). The mammals are represented by Cimolomys sp., Cimolodon sp., Alphadon sp., and possible Mesodma sp., but all are exceedingly rare. Sankey (1998) described the taxonomically similar Talley Mountain multituberculate/marsupial fauna as Judithian. As shown in Table 1 , nonmarine aquatic fauna at the Gaddis site includes Albanerpeton sp. and Scapherpeton sp. both of which were reported by Sankey (2008) and Rowe et al. (1992) in the Aguja. Abundant aquatic fauna includes Lepisosteus sp. which may also have lived in an estuarine setting (Hoese and Moore 1977; Bryant 1987 Bryant , 1989 . Lepisosteus sp. teeth and scales are the most abundant elements in the assemblage. Fauna listed in Table 1 as marine are Paralbula sp., Hybodus sp., Ischyrhiza avonicola, Restesia americana, and Myliobatis(?) sp. Seeds of the palm Sabal bigbendense (Manchester et al. 2010) are present. Rare eggshell fragments of the oogenus cf. Continuoolithus? (Zelenitsky et al. 1996) were recovered. Minor mmscale coprolites are present throughout the microfauna lens.

Of the approximately 2,500 microvertebrate bones, teeth, and eggshell fragments, only 53 elements (2.0%) exceed 5 mm in maximum dimension. The larger elements include vertebrae, other abraded bone, scutes, scales, teeth, and eggshell. Several of the larger elements at 10 mm or larger such as vertebrae or shell are cracked, and/or broken, and most of the larger elements have gypsum components. Given that none of this larger microfraction was observed during excavation, it is quite possible that they originated in a slightly different layer from the microvertebrates.

Unlike the microfauna at Rattlesnake Mt. (Sankey 2010) wherein elements were pristine to abraded, small element (, 5 mm) microvertebrate post mortem modification features at the Gaddis site (aside from breakage) are nonexistent. There is no evidence of exposure, weathering, or abrasion. None of the small-fraction elements contain gypsum intergrowth. This fraction also exhibits the three major types of bone fracture: transverse, longitudinal, and spiral. The dominant type is transverse, which is perpendicular to the long axis of a long bone. Some elements such as gar scales are sharply broken along the margins.

Vertebrate macrofossils from the Gaddis bonebed are components of a rich deposit that will be referred to as necessary to add data to this reconstruction. The bonebed is an approximately 40-m long, oblong horizon at the top of the ridge with fossils coming from the northwestern and southeastern portions of the horizon. A poorly defined high-angle fault separates the ends of the bonebed, and results in uncertainly about the precise stratigraphic correlation between the two. The presence of abundant turtle and plant fossils on the southeastern end and the complete lack of both on the northwestern end suggest the beds may not be coeval. The fossiliferous, gray, muddy siltstone layer at the southeastern end is slightly less than 1 m thick, and rests on hard, buff-colored siltstone. Yellowish nodules are found at the base of the southeastern part of the bonebed, and occasionally contain vertebrate elements. The northwestern end does not include these horizons at the base of that bonebed.

The fossiliferous layer on the southeastern end contains great quantities of wood (approximately one log section per square meter) that are present as both fossil charcoal (fusain) and in a permineralized state. Woody logs Scott (2010) . Key characteristics are black color, internal anatomy present, splintery/powdery, and lustrous coupled the observation that woody elements are only partially charred. Logs range up to 15 cm in diameter and approximately two meters in length. On the upper surface of the southeastern bonebed, common, branching vines (dicotyledonous vines) are oval to subround in cross section and average approximately 3 3 5 cm in diameter, and are parallel to the bedding plane at the top of the macrofossil bed. Identification of the vines was based on the detailed descriptions of Lewis (2011) . The vines are mostly well mineralized and are preserved predominantly in unburned condition with only thin (few mm across) fusain stringers running parallel to the vine axis in the outer layer.

Discoveries from this bonebed include dinosaurs, pterosaurs, crocodilians, turtles, and minor other vertebrates. There are no fish, amphibians, or invertebrates. Rare Ophiomorpha burrows approximately 5 mm in diameter are present in the southeast bed. No footprints or other ichnofossils are known from the bonebed. Work is ongoing, and discoveries occur regularly.

To date, the southeastern end of the macrofossil layers has produced approximately 130 recognizable fragmented or complete bones. Although specimen fragmentation complicates identification, approximately 70 of the more complete elements having been assigned to various taxa. Most fracture margins are sharp, and there is little to no evidence of subaerial exposure. While most elements are dissociated, numerous broken bones can be reassembled from adjacent fragments. In some cases, numerous fragments are part of these assemblies. This pit has produced two ceratopsians, one juvenile and one adult, six hadrosaurs ranging from a small individual, slightly longer than one half meter to a large juvenile at approximately 5 m in length, parts of a medium sized, juvenile tyrannosaur, and a juvenile Struthiomimus (Longrich et al. 2013) . Other elements include a tiny alligator jaw, rare fragments of pterosaur, and shed tyrannosaurid and Deinosuchus teeth. Tooth marks are present on a juvenile ceratopsian femur.

Turtles from this end of the layer deserve special attention because they are so abundant (up to 20% of the skeletal elements) in the southeastern pit, and they are fairly diverse. The most common representatives are trionychids (following the Tomlinson 1997 description) although Basilemys and Baena nodosa are also present. Most spectacular is the lateral rim with carpus and plastron of what is possibly a trionychid.

The northwestern end of the macrofossil layer has produced approximately 100 recognizable fragmented or complete bones. Preservation is excellent. An almost complete skeleton of an adult hadrosaur was recovered having skeletal elements that are fractured and contorted. Other discoveries are a somewhat scattered adult ceratopsian, elements of perhaps two species of tyrannosaurids, and a single Deinosuchus tooth. Also present are the bones of crocodilians and alligators.

Coprolites of possible dinosaurian origin are exceedingly rare in the Aguja Formation with only one specimen featured in the literature (Baghai-Riding and DiBenedetto 2001) . This specimen was recovered from the upper shale member, and was discovered to the east of the Gaddis site in Big Bend National Park. Other coprolites discovered in the Aguja were suggested by Sankey (2010) to be crocodilian.

Coprolites discovered on the surface of the ridge at the top of the stratigraphic section (above the northwestern end of the bonebed) complete the data for this paleoecology/paleocommunity assessment. All of the coprolites were found partially exposed in a single horizon in muddy gray siltstone two meters stratigraphically above the bonebed. No additional coprolites were discovered in scattered test pits excavated several cm deep into the coprolite surface. The only other fossils in this horizon include several poorly preserved and broken off logs approximately 2 to 3 m in length and a poorly preserved, vertical gymnosperm tree stump that appears to be in place. The only vertebrate remains in the coprolite horizon are two highly worn hadrosaur caudal centra from the northwestern end of the ridge.

Twenty-four coprolites in groupings of mostly two to four were found several meters apart over an area of approximately 150 m 2 directly above the western end of the bonebed and continuing west. They range from 5.6 g to 4.8 kg ( Table 2) . Identification of coprolites as dinosaurian is problematic for all but perhaps those specimens that are larger than other extant terrestrial animals could have produced. Chin (2007) reported coprolites from the Two Medicine Formation as having a volume of 6 to 7 L. The largest single specimen from the Gaddis site is 1.84 L, and samples range down to 0.002 L. The average mass for the collection is 642.0 g and the average volume is 233.9 mL with an average density of 2.6 g/mL. Several specimens were discovered in close groupings, such as A2b lying atop A2a for a total displacement of 0.65 L. Coprolite A1 was the only one discovered in isolation, but it is also the largest.

A few specimens were moved over more than a decade as work progressed in the macrovertebrate bonebed, so, in a few cases, precise original locations could not be determined by the time we collected them. From those that remained in undisturbed groupings, and with confidence based on the differentially siltstone in contact with those groupings, the original distance between groupings of coprolites was mostly between four and six meters.

The coprolites are coherent masses of apparently extruded morphologies (Fig. 6) as distinguished from non-biological masses such as the nodules that occur at the base of the bonebed. External details include small folds, bulges, flattening (impact?), pinch-offs, and variable vesicular porosity. A surprising discovery was coprolite A2b (Fig. 7) nestling precisely into a depression on the upper surface of A2a. While A2a has a highly vesicular surface, A2b is not. All of the coprolites have abundant plant material embedded into the surface including leaf impressions and woody stems. A deep crease in coprolite A11 precisely fits across an inserted thin branch. Coprolite A10 has bone visible on its surface and in thin section (Fig. 8) .

A few of the coprolites that were protruding from the horizon show signs of weathering with protruding lobes that are less rounded to concave compared with those that had remained mostly buried. Several fragments of the external surface were soaked in water to better gauge their resistance to disintegration. Surfaces that were competent when dry absorbed water and the surface began sloughing away upon agitation. These features suggest rather rapid disintegration upon exposure to rain.

At the Gaddis site the Aguja Formation progressively changes upsection from near shore marine through deltaic swamp to dry land paleoenvironments. Fossils characteristic of each of these settings are common in four distinct layers with mostly barren intervals between.

A mix of oysters and shark teeth in the basal bed suggest original deposition in a brackish bay. Using Galveston Bay, Texas, as a possible model of community structure, oysters are rare in marsh facies and more common in a brackish bay (Anderson et al. 2008) . Problematically, though, is that none of the hundreds of species of invertebrates commonly found in brackish bay environments are present in this outcrop. Given that a majority of these original inhabitants were probably soft-bodied, and many others were aragonitic, the taphonomic and diagenetic survivors would be calcitic. Also puzzling is the complete lack of foraminifers that would be expected to be present in a flourishing brackish bay setting. The presence of a silty matrix would argue against winnowing as a mechanism that might have removed foraminifers and other small, calcitic fossils. The fine fraction contains ubiquitous, highly degraded shell material. Perhaps foraminifera were not originally present, or they might have been dissolved at some point in a post-burial environment.

We interpret the origin and original deposition of the oysters and shark teeth as shallow, nearshore, and brackish water as oysters require brackish water (South Carolina Department of Natural Resources 2015). Beds containing oysters as the exclusive or almost exclusive fauna are common in the fossil record, and may be the results of oysters tolerating abnormal salinities or even fully saline waters for a limited time. The assemblage was likely reworked by transport, perhaps locally, as indicated by the severely broken and abraded nature of the oyster shells and the random, broken shark teeth. The oyster-encrusted hadrosaur tibia segment was conceivably the product of subaerial disarticulation, severe abrasion during both transport and probably following arrival on the oyster bank. The bone apparently had a relatively short residence time exposed in oysterproducing waters as it accumulated only patchy encrustations of tiny oysters.

Previously reported Aguja microsites contain abundant terrestrial faunas in addition to various other vertebrate elements (Rowe et al. 1992; Sankey 2008 ). Sankey (2010) reported deposition in interdistributary marsh-bay facies through inland floodplain facies. The Gaddis microsite contains a mixed fauna of mostly nearshore marine, common freshwater, and rare terrestrial components.

The sedimentological details of the lens are consistent with the area being a tidal channel on a deltaic floodplain. This observation is consistent with the pollen analysis of Baghai (1996) who determined environmental settings as suggested by palynomorphs from the corresponding stratigraphic interval at Rattlesnake Mountain located a few kilometers to the southeast. That setting was described as a fluvial channel on a lower delta plain bordering a neritic shore. Noted were the presence of woody fragments, sparse and degraded pollen, angiosperms, ferns, inertinite, and vitrinite (Baghai 1996) . While pollen was not analyzed, other components listed by Baghai are abundant in the Teredolites-microvertebrate lens.

The logs at the base of the microvertebrate lens provide a basis for paleoenvironmental interpretation. Infilled borings are attributed to the ichnotaxon Teredolites clavatus (Leymerie 1842) . Such borings are the product of teredinid and pholadid bivalves of allochthonous xylic material (Kelly and Bromley 1984) . Teredolites is considered a marine or brackish environmental indicator pointing to maximum flooding upon transgression in fluvial and estuarine systems (Moran et al. 2010) . Willapa Bay in Washington afforded an appropriate model for paleoecological reconstructions of Teredolites ichnofacies (Gingras et al. 2004 for a review). Associated Willapa Bay fauna includes Crassostrea that, coincidentally, occurs in the basal fossiliferous horizon at the Gaddis site, but is not found associated with the Teredolites. Thus, a shift from Crassostrea-rich sands in the bed below to brackish Teredolites facies is not a major facies change.

The bored logs are evidence of a likely depositional scenario that begins with inundation of a forested floodplain where xylic material was mobilized by tidal current or flooding. The log orientations of mostly NE-SW may have been roughly parallel to the course of a tidal inlet channel. All exposed surfaces of the logs would have been bored in nearshore environments not far from their points of origin (Savrda 1991) .

No logs have fine rootlets that are a characteristic of single (or brief) depositional events (Martin 1999 ). This is not surprising given the presence of such extensive borings. Thus, the logs apparently have a different depositional history compared to that of the overlying leaf layer although it is argued that the numerous logs with Teredolites borings in an associated woody horizon do constitute an ichnofacies as they were apparently bored in situ. An important observation also supporting relatively undisturbed emplacement is that the borings are infilled with mud identical to that found adjacent to the logs.

A reasonable interpretation for the origin of the logs with Teredolites borings within a scenario that includes the associated leaves and microvertebrates is possible when the Gaddis section is compared with an Upper Cretaceous shoreline sequence in Alberta described by Bromley et al. (1984) . That sequence consists mostly of sandstone, siltstone, and coal deposited in shallow marine to continental areas. Borings in logs are confined to areas that were directly overlain by a mud-filled tidal channel or inlet. Sandier deposits had no borings. Bromley et al. (1984) interpreted this particular type of area as having been deposited in a peat swamp upon lateral shift of the estuary. Such shifts may be rapid (Anderson et al. 2008) . Boring occurred only when the tidal channel was inundated for sufficient periods of time for the bivalves to survive.

Such a scenario would fit well with the location and boring of the logs, the deposition of thin sand stringers within siltstone packed with comminuted plant material, the subsequent collection of well-preserved leaves in mudstone, the accumulation of a microvertebrate local fauna that has a major shallow marine component, and final burial, all having occurred within a lower flow regime.

Some estimation of how long this periodic inundation may have lasted at the Gaddis site is provided by studies of the extant Teredo navalis (the common naval shipworm) that indicate pine poles can be consumed in 16 weeks and oak timber in 32 weeks (Didziulis 2014) . There is only one layer of bored logs at the Gaddis site, but the logs are thoroughly bored. Thus, this moment in time may have been exceedingly brief. Sediment filling and channel abandonment buried the Teredolites logs in silty mud (rich in comminuted plant material) in life position as indicated by the under sides of all but one log having remained unbored.

Mud with a sparse silt-sized mineral component may suggest deposition in a swamp rather than in an active fluvial channel. The presence of comminuted leaf material in thin sand stringers within silty mudstone above the Teredolites layer may indicate time averaging of approximately six months to five years (Martin 1999) for this few-cm thick layer between the logs and the microvertebrates. The comminuted leaf material exceeds rock-derived sediment in volume, a condition common to clastic swamps (Martin 1999) .
The configuration of the microvertebrate lens suggests that abundant plant material and masses of leaves collected in a topographic low.

Numerous, mostly complete leaves below the microvertebrate layer suggest deposition at low current velocity or, perhaps, by settling from suspension (Wilson 2006) . Relatively rapid deposition is suggested by evidence that leaves typically decompose in two weeks to five years, and they are highly unlikely to be reworked (Martin 1999) . Dry leaves also crumble and degrade rapidly due to the action of microbes (Burnham 1993) . Mostly whole leaves, as is the case herein, are considered to be a hallmark of a brief time of accumulation (Burnham 1993) . Aside from rare sabal palm seeds, no other seeds were noted in this interval.

There are no articulated microvertebrate remains, an observation that suggests that most or even all of the microvertebrate elements are simply dissociated and isolated. Taphonomic variation and taxonomic composition are related to hydrodynamic forces that vary with depositional system (Behrensmeyer 1988; Brett and Speyer 1990; Blob and Fiorillo 1996) . Wilson (2006) compared a mudstone deposit to a sandstone deposit. The mudstone was dominated by tabular, low density components such as cycloid scales and fish vertebrae, and the sandstone contained mostly highdensity, equidimensional elements such as teeth, ganoid scales, and turtle shell fragments. The implication of this research is that the abundance of ganoid scales, teeth, and numerous other equidimensional elements would be expected in sandstone matrix rather than enclosed in the silty mudstone of the microsite lens at the Gaddis site.

Assemblage and taphonomic data suggest the Gaddis microvertebrate site is a local fauna that underwent transport within a low flow regime. Microelements were transported and sorted by low energy tidal processes although the few broken and/or abraded larger size fraction (. 10 mm) probably had a different depositional history from that of the smaller sized-fraction (, 5 mm). The disarticulated assemblage was sorted and transported a short distance whereupon it collected in a slight topographic low. This attritional assemblage is apparently a collection from several adjacent communities, a sampling process described by Behrensmeyer (1982) . Evidence suggests that the microvertebrate communities collected in this lens would have originated predominantly in nearshore, shallow non-marine to marine waters as well as being washed in from adjacent terrestrial environments (Table 1) . Thus, the taphonomic histories of the components in the microvertebrate lens appear to be complex. It is suggested that the few large and abraded elements (hadrosaur caudal centra, ankylosaur dermal bone, and a juvenile crocodilian centrum) were perhaps transported into the lens by bank slumping or a similar process as there is no evidence of a current sufficient to move these larger specimens.

There is possible evidence of micropredation in the form of long bones that exhibit unmodified, sharp-edged, spiral and longitudinal fractures. No tooth marks were noted upon microscopic examination. Fractures normal to the axis of long bones are interpreted as likely having occurred following fossilization (Myers et al. 1980) . Spiral fractures are characteristic of bones that are broken while fresh, or even while living (Myers et al. 1980) . Longitudinal fractures, those parallel to the long axis of a long bone, are rare, and they are present mostly on hollow long bones. These could be the result of loading, but predation might also be a cause. Surface cracks in the rare larger elements are interpreted as a result of subaerial exposure for an extended period of time, and the presence of gypsum, although abundant, is evidence of being subjected to pedogenesis.

A comparison to the well-studied Rattlesnake Mountain section using the 12 observations made by Sankey (2010) is instructive for assessing the variations in fauna, and, thus, the differences in environments of deposition and paleoecology between the two microvertebrate sites ( Table 3 ). The differences are worth noting. The Gaddis site has a much stronger aquatic signature, and it lacks or has significantly reduced numbers of many of the terrestrial fossils. Theropod evidence is absent in this interval at the Gaddis site. No invertebrates are known at the Gaddis site.

Bonebeds from other Aguja outcrops were apparently the products of dinosaurs dying near drying sources of water, lying exposed, being trampled and scattered, and finally undergoing transport and burial (Lehman 1982 (Lehman , 1989 Davies and Lehman 1989) . This established scenario does not apply to the macrovertebrate bonebed at the Gaddis site. The area was perhaps a swamp as indicated by the presence of copious leaf material and logs distributed in churned mud. These logs are all unbored, quite unlike logs in the Teredolites layer. Paleoenvironmental associations noted for various species present in the Gaddis bonebed include the presence of Agujaceratops mariscalensis within coastal floodplains (Sankey 2010 ) that were likely densely vegetated and marshy. The bonebed at the Gaddis site was likely an interdistributary swamp following the description of Lehman (1982) in the Aguja Formation gray mudstone with dinosaurs that are disarticulated but have not been winnowed. Plant remains are abundant. Other possibilities are that the interval may have been deposited as an overbank deposit or even in a lacustrine environment. The interval will be referred to as swamp or swampy, but this cannot be conclusively established.

The presence of abundant jarosite in the interval above the microvertebrate layer is interpreted as evidence that the accumulation of organic matter occurred under waterlogged conditions in the presence of sulfate (Kraus 1998) . Sulfide-rich soils were common during the Late Cretaceous retreat of the Western Interior Seaway in conjunction with humid conditions (Kraus 1998) . The siltstone containing coprolites at the top of the ridge is lighter in color and is devoid of jarosite suggesting that the soils were well drained at that point in the overall drying that occurred in this stratigraphic section.

At the southeastern end of the bonebed, evidence for trampling within unconsolidated sediment is probable in the form of five high-angle plunging long bones in churned mud similar in appearance to an occurrence reported by Montgomery and Barnes (2012) in the overlying Javelina Formation. Plunging bones include an approximately 15-cm long partial femur at 908 to the bedding plane with the proximal end up, and another femur of similar plunge but missing both ends. Both femora exhibit weathering, although one is weathered on the distal third and the other on the proximal third. A Struthiomimus tibia plunged at a 458 angle.

The remains recovered from the northwestern pit include a nearly complete and only slightly disarticulated hadrosaur unlike anything recovered in the other pit. Although the northwestern pit includes numerous disarticulated bones, none show evidence of sedimentary transport like that found in the southeastern pit. Plunging long bones, vines, or burned wood were not discovered from the northwestern pit.

Evidence of predation at the Gaddis site was presented by Schwimmer (2002) who reported on three hadrosaur (probably Kritosaurus sp.) caudal vertebra from two different animals, vertebra that are now in the Texas Memorial Museum collection. One caudal vertebra is pitted with numerous blunt bite marks interpreted as having been produced by Deinosuchus (Schwimmer 2002) . The lack of cracking indicates that the bone was fresh and wet when it was chewed (Schwimmer 2002) . The other two vertebrae have only one dimple each with one of the dimples exhibiting the same morphology as the pits in the first vertebra. The third has an irregular mark associated with shattering.

We agree with Schwimmer (2002) that the well-chewed caudal was the likely product of a fresh kill with a Deinosuchus having thoroughly chewed the fleshy tail. The other two vertebrae do not present such clear evidence of predation. Beyond the dramatic nature of this feeding evidence is the importance of this site in any discussion about Deinosuchus feeding on dinosaurs. Such was almost assuredly the case in the Aguja Formation, at the overlap of nearshore areas occupied by Deinosuchus and hadrosaurs.

An almost complete skeleton of an adult hadrosaur in the northwestern pit presents strong evidence for predation. Bite marks are present on the ilium of this adult hadrosaur, and its calcaneum and astragalus have several grooves, gouges, and chewed-off areas. Recent work by one of us (Clark) suggests that the grooves were likely produced by a large tyrannosaurid as evidenced by the precise fit of this tooth into the grooves. None of the three bones is cracked or broken to an extent that would suggest the culprit was a powerful adult. It is unknown why bites would be present on the ankle. Perhaps the predator was moving the prey. Additionally, the essentially complete cervical string of this animal shows no evidence of predation that, if perforated, might be an indication of predation by a theropod. No evidence of healing is present, so the injuries were inflicted either immediately pre-death or post mortem. As this hadrosaur was an adult, it is assumed that the predator was large. Bite mark morphology is consistent with a tyrannosaurid having been the aggressor.

Tyrannosaurid teeth carved into bone while crocodilian teeth scored shallow grooves and punctured deep pits (Longrich et al. 2010) . The Uand V-shaped grooves are of varying width, length, and cross-sectional pattern. Puncture pits are of varying diameter and depth. We assume that large circular punctures and U-shaped grooves (Fig. 9) were produced by crocodilians as shed teeth from the site precisely fit into the damaged areas. A 7 cm tyrannosaur tooth fits perfectly into one of the punctures.

A juvenile hadrosaur tibia has small predation marks that are probably not tyrannosaurid, but were likely produced by a smaller unknown predator. A fourth bone is a juvenile hadrosaur femur, and again, the teeth marks are small and not especially deep. One juvenile hadrosaur tibia has bite marks running transversely across the bone (Fig. 10) . The laterally compressed dentary or maxillary teeth of theropods may have produced V- shaped grooves and small oval punctures. Shed theropod teeth from multiple locations in the macrovertebrate layer fit precisely into these grooves and punctures. A section of a medium-sized hadrosaur femur is shattered and torn away on both ends in what appears to be the result of gnawing, but it remains unclear whether a theropod or a crocodile inflicted this damage. A juvenile ceratopsian femur shows evidence of tooth marks by a possible raptor based on the precise fit of a tooth in the groove. Small marks are approximately 2.5 mm wide and 1 mm deep. We sought to discover why so many diverse, disarticulated bones in the southeast pit ended up in this apparent swamp. Deposition of the upper Aguja occurred during a time of warm temperatures and a relatively high sea level stand (Atchley et al. 2004) . As there is no evidence of fish or invertebrate occupation, this presumed swamp is assumed to have been ephemeral and more of a depression filled with muddy water and plant debris than a persistent pond. It also may have dried seasonally, but there is no local carbonate cementation or pedogenic nodule evidence. Abundant fossil remains suggest the presence of at least periodic, and occasionally large populations of dinosaurs in the area.

The role turtles may have played in assembling the diverse collection of skeletal elements in this swamp is worthy of exploration. Curiously, all of the turtles are disarticulated. Aside from the previously noted bones that are punctured or cut, no other bones are marked. Additionally, most bones show no evidence of subaerial exposure and little evidence of transport. A hypothetical mechanism for accumulation of this skeletal assemblage is having turtles drag various disarticulated, but not completely defleshed, carrion elements into the swamp. The exception to this mechanism is the one large, intact hadrosaur, but it may have been killed where it was found. Further details about this skeleton and about many of the other vertebrate remains will emerge. Work conducted by one of us (Clark) and his colleagues is ongoing.

The descriptions of the platanoid vines in the Aguja Formation described by Lewis (2011) precisely match the woody vines in the southeast Gaddis macrovertebrate bonebed. Platanoids were common elements in channel deposits at this time (Wing and Boucher 1998) . Additional similarities include the presence of hadrosaurs, minimal transport, and the suggestion that the carcasses were disarticulated in the same mudstone in which they were discovered. Woody vines are a vital component of the ecology of forests as they are an important food source for fauna, they bind trees together in the canopy, and they promote tree mortality (Putz and Mooney 1991; Schnitzer and Bongers 2002) . Cretaceous platanoids were especially common in stream margin environments (Wing and Boucher 1998) .

The thin, powdery charcoal bands along the vines have all the characteristics of fusain described by Scott (1989) as a product of wildfire or hot volcanic products (not applicable in this case). If, indeed, a wildfire passed through the area partially burning the vines, the various vertebrates present may have suffered injury and death. Almost certainly, those that were able would have reacted by fleeing. Given their limited mobility, young are more vulnerable to injury and death in this situation than are mature animals (Smith 2000) . Although speculative, wildfire may have caused or contributed to the high percentage of juvenile versus adult dinosaurs in the bonebed (Lyon et al. 2000) . Support for this idea is found in the half dozen juveniles in the southeast bonebed along with only two digits from larger juvenile hadrosaurs.

The dry land interval is marked by a coprolite surface that is perhaps the unique feature of the Gaddis site as an extensive collection of coprolites such as this is unknown in the Aguja Formation. Plants visible in thin section suggest that some of the coprolites may have been produced by herbivores. The one coprolite containing bone (A10) probably cannot be associated with crocodiles that are clearly present in the bone bed below this level. Baghai-Riding and DiBenedetto (2001) noted that crocodilian feces have a characteristic ''corkscrew appearance''. Neither coprolite A10 nor any other Gaddis site coprolites have a corkscrew morphology. None exhibit the sausage-like sphincter imprints described by Schwimmer (2002) from Hannahatchee Creek, Georgia as being possible Deinosuchus coprolites although he also noted amorphous shapes as being possible candidates. All of the coprolites were apparently deposited on a wellvegetated surface as indicated by the impressions and shallow incorporation of ferns, stems, and other ground cover on the surfaces of the coprolites that only a freshly deposited dropping would incorporate. Finally, none of the coprolites appears to have been moved post deposition. Coherent groupings remained.

Aside from the presence of damaged bones that are a record of predation, no unequivocal evidence of dinosaurian diet exists at the Gaddis site below the coprolite level. Coprolites may provide at least limited testimony at this horizon, if they can be confidently associated with specific animal groups and if evidence of the original food material remains and has not decomposed beyond recognition nor been obliterated upon mineralization.

Plant materials in thin sections include woody components encapsulated within the coprolites. A comparison may be found in the Upper Cretaceous Two Medicine Formation of Wyoming. As discussed by Chin (2007) , woody material is eaten on a regular basis by a range of vertebrates that includes elephants, deer, beaver, and turtles. Ingestion of woody material increases during times of the year when a dearth of nitrogen-rich food items occurs (Mattson 1980) . Until more definitive data are obtained, one possibility among many is that the abundant amber throughout the bonebed was an original byproduct of dinosaur-induced damage to woody plants during a similar time of year. All thin sections include dispersed silt and sand-sized mineral grains perhaps incorporated during regular consumption of food items on the ground. Chin (2007) associated the Two Medicine coprolites with Maiasaura based on size, composition, and context. Maiasaura are common to that area, and they possessed dental batteries capable of reducing wood to the pulverized state observed in thin section of these coprolites. Chin (2007) also noted that dinosaurs for which there is little or no skeletal evidence might have produced other specimens. The Aguja coprolite of Baghai-Riding and DiBenedetto (2001) had dimensions of 15 3 9 3 12 cm, a size that is similar to several of the Gaddis specimens, but certainly smaller than the larger ones presented in this report. Baghai-Riding and DiBenedetto (2001) suggested that coprolite was produced by a large herbivorous dinosaur. Given the abundance of hadrosaurs in the underlying macrovertebrate bed, and the presence of two hadrosaur centra on the coprolite surface, there is circumstantial evidence that at least some of the coprolites might have been produced by these herbivores although the possibility remains that particularly the smaller coprolites may have been produced by a range of animals. The one coprolite containing bone (A10) is of possible carnivore origin although the prey item remains unidentified.

The Gaddis site in the Aguja Formation of the Big Bend of Texas includes diagnostic fossil sets that permit detailed paleoenvironmental reconstruction of the change from nearshore marine through tidal channel to swamp and, finally, to dry land during the Late Cretaceous. The site also improves our knowledge of the overall paleogeographic and paleoecological models of the Aguja Formation.

Important details in the tidal channel interval feature logs with Teredolites borings that were likely only exposed for a few months and are overlain by leaves and then a rich assemblage of microvertebrates. When considered in a time-averaged framework, local fossil assemblages suggest that a particularly ephemeral moment was recorded. The diverse macrovertebrate bed documents predation/scavenging on several animals by perhaps several predators and/or scavengers. The southeast macrovertebrate bed also includes a record of flash fires and the resulting dearth of adult animals that apparently fled more readily than did the young. Finally, a wealth of probable dinosaur coprolites is indication of mostly herbivores and at least one carnivore existing on a single well-vegetated, but dry land surface.

Research at the Gaddis site remains incomplete. Future work is focusing on geochemical analysis of the microvertebrates, coprolites, and fusain that will permit a highly detailed reconstruction of the paleoecology of this Aguja Formation interval. An attempt will also be made to identify the collection of relatively well-preserved leaves.

back_matter.text: We would like to thank two anonymous reviewers for their careful and constructive comments. The Gaddis family has always been supportive of this work on their land. Larry Millar is a regular companion, keen observer, and tireless worker at the site. Numerous high school students from the Abilene area, from St. Stephens School in Austin, and college students from the University of Texas at Dallas worked at the site. Mr. Ken Barnes provided assistance over the years of field work.Gaddis site fossils are cataloged with the Texas Memorial Museum in Austin (TMM45920, 45921, 45922). TMM45921 and TMM45922 include the bonebed, specimens from which are described in other publications. TMM45920 is the newly discovered microvertebrate lens, but none of the individual fossils were specifically noted before shipment to and archiving at TMM.

plant fragments, clay balls, snail steinkerns.Few clay balls. No invertebrate fossils.
